newsitem.title: BRAZIL: HSBC redraws Brazil banking landscape.
newsitem.headline: HSBC redraws Brazil banking landscape.

text.p: Brazil's banking landscape has been redrawn virtually overnight after Anglo-Asian financial mammoth HSBC Holdings Plc bought out its Brazilian partner in a bid to lead the country's retail banking industry, analysts said.

With its $1.0 billion acquisition of Banco Bamerindus do Brasil SA, HSBC has made a major commitment to Latin America's biggest economy and will probably force local competitors to rethink future expansion plans, analysts said.

"Banks will have to review their strategies to compete with the new player," said Gilberto Nobre, vice-president at Banco Excel Economico, a bank which itself has shaken the competition with its aggressive approach to clients.
"I'll bet that at every meeting, at every bank, across the country on Monday, executives sat down to debate how they would face up to their new competitor," Nobre said.

Under a deal announced Wednesday by Bazil's Central Bank HSBC assumed 10 billion reais of the former Bamerimdus' assets and liabilities and estabilished a new bank under the name of Banco HSBC Bamerindus SA.
The new bank, a fully HSBC owned subsidiary, opened for business on Monday, and has already announced plans to expand its network to 1,500 branches from the current 1,206.
Analysts said HSBC will probably shake up Brazil's conservative retail banking sector.
"For the first time a large bank with recognized international experience in retail banking is entering the Brazilian market," said Erivelto Rodrigues, analyst at Austin Asis banking consulting firm.
Rodrigues pointed out that at an estimated $400 billion, HSBC's total worldwide assets are nearly equivalent to all of Brazil's bank assets.
Analysts said HSBC will force Brazilian retail banks to invest in new cost-effective services to keep abreast of the latest in international banking technology.

Caught offguard by HSBC's surprise entry into the market, board members at some of Brazil's most-firmly established banks said they were well-prepared to face the new competition. They said the country's banking sector can only win with the presence of the Anglo-Asian bank.

"HSBC is undoubtedly a strong competitor...In the medium term, HSBC will contribute to make the market more agile," said Roberto Setubal, president of Banco Itau SA, Brazil's second largest private bank.

Over the past two years, Brazilian banks have undergone a brutal transformation, which was triggered by the three year-old stabilization plan which slashed inflation and eliminated the banks' almost risk-free profits.
Several small, and even some large and traditional, financial institutions were forced to close doors or merge in an effort to survive.
For the banking industry, the positive side of the anti-inflation program was an increase in the average Brazilian's purchasing power.
Economists estimate around 30 million people have crossed the poverty line since the launch of the Real Plan, increasing demand for credit and banking services.
"Those new consumers are the banks' new target," Excel Economico's Nobre said.
Analysts also said HSBC opened doors for new foreign banks to invest in Brazil.
"The HSBC move is likely to lead other foreign financial conglomerates to think over opportunities in the Brazilian market," said Itau's Setubal.
Opportunities may come with the upcoming privatizations of state banks like Banerj and Credireal.
((--Sao Paulo Newsroom 5511 2485412))
